questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of pruritus and a hypopigmented rash on his upper body for 5 days. He first noticed the symptoms after returning from a business trip last week in the Bahamas. While he was there, he visited a couple of beaches and went hiking with some coworkers. The rash initially started as a single lesion on his upper back but since then has extended to his shoulders. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with an insulin pump. He works as an office manager and has no known exposure to melanocytotoxic chemicals. He has been sexually active with three female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. One month ago, his hemoglobin A1C was 7.8%. Which of the following studies is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dermoscopy may be used ancillary in patients with pityriasis versicolor, where it shows well-demarcated, white areas with fine whitish scaling localized in the skin furrows. It does not confirm the diagnosis. Dermoscopy is also used to exclude malignant lesions such as melanoma and basal cell carcinoma. However, neither of the two lesions causes widespread hypopigmentation, nor would they spread so rapidly and superficially.

B) INCORRECT:

A Wood lamp examination may support the diagnosis of pityriasis versicolor by revealing a yellow-green fluorescence. However, this finding is not specific for pityriasis versicolor and can be seen in other conditions (e.g., dermatophyte infections), making Wood lamp examination a poor confirmatory test.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of thyroid stimulation hormone (TSH) is the best first test to diagnose hypothyroidism. Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism and is strongly associated with vitiligo. Vitiligo can present with well-demarcated hypopigmented macules, but they are not pruritic or scaly like the lesions seen here. Additionally, this patient has no clinical features of hypothyroidism, such as constipation, bradycardia, myxedema, fatigue, cold intolerance, or a hoarse voice.

D) INCORRECT:

Skin culture is commonly used for fungal or bacterial infections if the diagnosis is unclear after performing more rapid tests. Although skin cultures are cost-effective, they are time-consuming and can delay adequate treatment. In pityriasis versicolor, skin culture is often reported to be negative, because Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur, the pathogens causing pityriasis versicolor, are difficult to grow under laboratory conditions.

E) CORRECT:

The diagnosis of pityriasis versicolor is often made clinically but can be confirmed with potassium hydroxide preparation of a skin scraping, which is acquired by scraping the affected area with a scalpel or a glass slide. A positive test shows hyphae and spores resembling spaghetti and meatballs on microscopy. Pityriasis versicolor is most commonly caused by the fungi Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. Skin lesions typically manifest as hyperpigmented or hypopigmented macules or patches. Individuals with light skin, such as this patient, often become aware of the disease after sun exposure because the lesions do not tan and become more visible against the surrounding skin.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin scraping

Throughout the image, there are multiple short, septated hyphae (filamentous structures) and spherical spores. These different morphological forms are responsible for the “spaghetti and meatballs” pattern (hyphae being the spaghetti and yeast being the meatballs), which is a typical finding of Malassezia furfur.

F) INCORRECT:

Punch biopsy is an important test in cases of suspected skin infection or malignancy. While infection with Mycobacterium leprae may also manifest with hypopigmented patches on the shoulders, other symptoms of leprosy such as loss of sensation, muscle weakness, poor eyesight, and painless lumps on the face or earlobes would also be expected. Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma as well may manifest with hypopigmented patches, but this variant predominates in children rather than in a 21-year old man. Classic cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presents with red, scaly, pruritic, well-demarcated skin plaques and patches, mushroom-shaped tumors, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly in the later stages of the disease. Histopathological evaluation would show atypical CD4+ T-cells in the dermis and epidermis and Pautrier microabscesses. While a punch biopsy in a patient with pityriasis versicolor would show spores and short hyphae within the stratum corneum on histopathology, a less invasive test is preferred to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: The picture shows localized, well-circumscribed, hypopigmented macules with fine scaling indicative of pityriasis versicolor.

questions.text: A potassium hydroxide preparation is conducted on a skin scraping of the hypopigmented area. Microscopy of the preparation shows long hyphae among clusters of yeast cells. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic fluconazole may be used in the treatment of pityriasis versicolor. However, given its many adverse side effects (e.g., hepatotoxicity, seizures, gastrointestinal distress), this drug is only used to treat severe and widespread forms of pityriasis versicolor or if topical therapy is ineffective.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids such as clobetasol or mometasone are used in autoimmune diseases like guttate psoriasis or vitiligo, which also cause hypopigmentation. Vitiligo commonly presents with hypopigmented lesions on the extremities that do not have a scaly appearance, as seen in this patient. While guttate psoriasis can present with hypopigmentation, pinkish papules with a fine scale are more common and they tend to occur over a period of 2–3 months rather than 5 days, as seen in the patient here. Corticosteroids are therefore not only not indicated, they would actually worsen the fungal infection with their immunosuppressive effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic ketoconazole may be used in the treatment of fungal infections, such as pityriasis versicolor. However, given its many adverse side effects (e.g., hepatotoxicity, adrenal injury) and drug interactions, this drug is only used to treat severe and widespread fungal infections. Topical ketoconazole may be used to treat pityriasis versicolor.

D) CORRECT:

Selenium sulfide is an antifungal agent used to treat tinea versicolor infections. It is available as a shampoo or lotion. The shampoo is used for scalp lesions as well as seborrheic dermatitis, whereas lotion is typically used for skin lesions not occurring on the scalp. Selenium sulfide promotes epidermal turnover, especially of the stratum corneum, which is the layer infected by Malassezia furfur, the causative organism of tinea versicolor. If topical therapy fails or the disease is severe and widespread, oral antifungals such as fluconazole are used.

E) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is used to treat local infections with Candida, which would show pseudohyphae and budding yeast cells on a KOH preparation. Candidal infections of the skin cause a red, itchy rash and not the hypopigmented lesions observed in this patient. It is not effective against Malassezia furfur, the causative organism of tinea versicolor.
questions.hint: The presence of long hyphae among clusters of yeast cells is typical of the “spaghetti and meatball” appearance seen in Malassezia furfur infections.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of a rash on his chest and back. His mother initially noticed only a few lesions on his back, but since then the rash has spread to his chest. His family returned from a trip to the Caribbean 2 weeks ago. His mother started using a new laundry detergent 8 days ago. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin. His mother has Hashimoto thyroiditis and his brother has severe facial acne. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 81/min, and blood pressure is 115/74 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows multiple, nontender, round, white macules on the chest and trunk. There is fine scaling when the lesions are scraped with a spatula. There are no excoriation marks. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes may play a role in the development of vitiligo. This theory is supported by the fact that almost 20% of patients with vitiligo patients have coexisting autoimmune diseases. Although this patient has a personal and family history of autoimmune diseases (type 1 DM and Hashimoto thyroiditis), vitiligo typically manifests with nonscaling, well-demarcated, depigmented macules.
Image Description:

Localization: dorsal aspect of the forearm

Lesion: characteristic, well demarcated, irregularly shaped, white macules

B) INCORRECT:

Increased sebum production has been implicated in the development of acne vulgaris. The characteristic finding in acne vulgaris is the presence of comedones, however, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, areas with increased sebaceous activity are susceptible to seborrheic dermatitis, which typically presents with pruritic erythematous plaques with patchy scaling distributed along areas with hair and oily skin; however, this patient's nonpruritic macules distributed on the chest and trunk are unlikely to be due to seborrheic dermatitis.
Image Description:

Chest of a male patient

Erythema with fine scaling is visible between and underneath the breasts.

These findings are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trichophyton rubrum can cause tinea corporis infection, which typically manifests with a round, pruritic, erythematous plaque that grows centrifugally, with central clearing, scaling, and a raised border. This patient's presentation with nonpruritic (no excoriation marks) macules is unlikely to be due to tinea corporis infection.
Image Description:

An erythematous patch with mild scaling and central clearing is seen on the left wrist.

These features are characteristic of dermatophyte fungal infection.

D) CORRECT:

Pityriasis versicolor is most commonly caused by increased growth of Malassezia globosa or other fungi of the Malassezia genus (e.g., Malassezia furfur), which belong to the physiological flora of the skin. Affected individuals typically present with abnormal pigmentation (can vary from white to brown or reddish-brown) involving the trunk, chest, back, and/or abdomen following a history of travel to a humid and warm place, such as the Caribbean. Both higher temperatures and humidity provide an ideal environment for the pathogen, which predisposes to overgrowth. The lesions become more apparent after UV exposure or tanning because the surrounding skin gets darker, which provides greater contrast to the lesions. Topical antifungals are the first-line therapy, e.g., selenium sulfide lotion or shampoo, topical ketoconazole, or terbinafine.
Image Description:

Multiple hypopigmented macules (after UV exposure) are visible on this patient's back.

This appearance is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor.

E) INCORRECT:

Viral exposure such as HHV-7 may be involved in the development of pityriasis rosea, which typically initially manifests with a herald patch followed by secondary eruption of bilateral, diffuse, oval-shaped, salmon-colored papules and plaques distributed on the trunk along the skin cleavage lines.
Image Description:

A secondary rash after primary plaque formation (not shown) can be seen on the back of this patient. The secondary eruption of pityriasis rosea is usually episodic and distributed along Langer lines.

F) INCORRECT:

Corynebacterium minutissimum is part of the normal human flora. However, under favorable conditions (heat and high humidity, typically provided by most skin fold areas), these organisms proliferate, causing erythrasma. Although erythrasma is prevalent among diabetic patients, it is rare in children and typically appears in intertriginous areas (not on the chest and trunk).
Image Description:

There is a ∼ 15-cm red-brown, sharply demarcated, distally extending patch in the right groin area, which shows partial scaling.

This is the typical appearance of erythrasma.

G) INCORRECT:

Antigen uptake by Langerhans cells plays a role in the pathophysiology of type IV hypersensitivity reactions such as allergic contact dermatitis, which can be caused by laundry detergent and typically manifests with a rash. However, the rash associated with a type IV hypersensitivity reaction is typically intensely papular, pruritic, and erythematous, with edema, vesicles, and/or oozing, corresponding to the areas of contact with the external irritant. This patient's nonpruritic (no excoriation marks) macules with no specific pattern of distribution are unlikely to be due to allergic contact dermatitis.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.
questions.hint: The eruption of multiple, nontender, and nonpruritic white macules with fine scaling after traveling to a warm, humid climate should raise suspicion for pityriasis versicolor.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 32-year-old woman presents with a new rash that she noticed a few weeks ago. There are numerous thin, oval, scaly, pink, and hypopigmented patches distributed over her chest, shoulders, and back (figure).
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s rash?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis rosea often manifests as a single, annular plaque on the neck or trunk (a herald patch), followed 1 to 3 weeks later by a papulosquamous eruption that occurs in the skin tension lines of the body (Langer lines) and therefore adopts a Christmas tree pattern on the trunk. A KOH preparation of pityriasis rosea would be negative.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitiligo is depigmented (not hypopigmented) and is devoid of scale. Treated tinea versicolor will lose its scale, but it is never completely devoid of pigment like vitiligo.

C) CORRECT:

Tinea (or pityriasis) versicolor is a common superficial fungal disorder caused by Malassezia furfur. It characteristically manifests as multiple thin, oval, hypo- or hyperpigmented, scaly papules and plaques. It is most commonly distributed over lipid-rich areas of the body, including the trunk, proximal arms, and occasionally the neck and face. It may itch.

Affected patients are usually adolescents or young adults who have robust sebum production (oily skin); it is not typically found in older adults, given the relative reduction of sebum production with age, unless they live in warm, humid climates. The diagnosis is often made clinically but can be confirmed by visualizing hyphae and spores on skin scrapings prepared with potassium hydroxide (KOH).

Tinea versicolor usually responds to topical antifungal preparations, either dandruff shampoos or topical antifungal creams, but the condition can be chronic and recurrent because the organism is part of the normal flora. To prevent recurrence, treatment should be followed by maintenance use of the topical preparation. The pigmentary changes can take months to years to resolve.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young woman with thin, oval, scaly, hypopigmented plaques on the chest, shoulders, and back is tinea versicolor.

D) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis — a superficial fungal infection found anywhere on the body — manifests as erythematous, annular scaly plaques that may develop central clearing. A KOH examination of skin scrapings can be diagnostic and appears different from that of tinea versicolor. Tinea corporis can also be confirmed with a fungal culture, whereas Malassezia furfur does not grow well in culture.

E) INCORRECT:

Nummular eczema manifests with extremely pruritic, discrete, annular, erythematous, oozing/weeping plaques in the acute phase and thickened, darkened eczematous patches in the chronic phase. A KOH preparation would be negative.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of a rash on the back. The rash is shown. The rash shows numerous hypopigmented, well-demarcated macules are visible on the patient's back. The lesions show fine scaling and coalesce in some regions. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral terbinafine is not an effective treatment for pityriasis versicolor.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is an antibiotic that can treat skin and soft tissue bacterial infections, but it is not effective against fungal infections such as pityriasis versicolor.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Topical clotrimazole is an azole antifungal that effectively treats pityriasis versicolor. Topical therapy is first-line treatment for localized disease and has fewer adverse effects and lower cost compared to systemic alternatives.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical mupirocin is an antibiotic ointment that can treat skin and soft tissue bacterial infections, but it is not effective against fungal infections such as pityriasis versicolor.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral griseofulvin is not an effective treatment for pityriasis versicolor.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a nonpruritic rash on his chest for 1 week. He returned from a trip to Puerto Rico 10 days ago. He started using a new laundry detergent after returning. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin. His mother has Hashimoto thyroiditis, and his sister has severe facial acne. Examination of the skin shows multiple, nontender, round, hypopigmented macules on the chest and trunk. There is fine scaling when the lesions are scraped with a spatula. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes likely plays a role in the development of vitiligo. This theory is supported by the fact that ∼ 20% of patients with vitiligo have a comorbid autoimmune disease. This patient has a personal and family history of autoimmune disease (type 1 diabetes mellitus and Hashimoto thyroiditis). However, vitiligo typically manifests with nonscaling, depigmented (rather than hypopigmented) macules.
Image Description:

Localization: dorsal aspect of the forearm

Lesion: characteristic, well demarcated, irregularly shaped, white macules

B) INCORRECT:

Increased sebum production is implicated in the development of acne vulgaris. The characteristic finding in acne vulgaris is the presence of comedones, however, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, areas with increased sebaceous activity are susceptible to seborrheic dermatitis. This condition manifests with pruritic erythematous plaques with patchy scaling distributed along areas with hair and oily skin, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

Chest of a male patient

Erythema with fine scaling is visible between and underneath the breasts.

These findings are consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Tyrosinase is an enzyme in melanocytes that produces melanin from dihydroxyphenylalanine. A deficiency in tyrosinase leads to oculocutaneous albinism, which manifests as greatly reduced or complete lack of pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes in newborns. The development of isolated hypopigmented macules in an adolescent is not consistent with tyrosinase deficiency.
Image Description:

Absence of melanin results in white hair and very light skin. The eyes appear red because the absence of melanin in the iris and retinal pigment epithelium allows the underlying blood vessels to shine through in the right lighting conditions.

D) CORRECT:

Pityriasis versicolor is most commonly caused by increased growth of Malassezia globosa or other fungi of the Malassezia genus (e.g., Malassezia furfur), which belong to the physiological flora of the skin. Affected individuals typically present with abnormal pigmentation (can vary from white to brown or reddish-brown) involving the trunk, back, and/or abdomen following a history of travel to a humid and warm place, such as the Caribbean. Both higher temperatures and humidity provide an ideal environment for the pathogen, which predisposes to overgrowth. The lesions become more apparent after UV exposure or tanning because the surrounding skin gets darker, which provides greater contrast to the lesions.

Topical antifungals are the first-line therapy, e.g., selenium sulfide lotion or shampoo, topical ketoconazole, or terbinafine.
Image Description:

Multiple hypopigmented macules (after UV exposure) are visible on this patient's back.

This appearance is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor.

E) INCORRECT:

Antigen uptake by Langerhans cells plays a role in the pathophysiology of type IV hypersensitivity reactions such as allergic contact dermatitis, which typically presents with an intensely pruritic, erythematous, and papular rash in a pattern corresponding to the areas of contact with the external irritant. This patient's nonpruritic (no excoriation marks) macules with no specific pattern of distribution are unlikely to be due to allergic contact dermatitis.

Laundry detergents are a common cause of irritant contact dermatitis, a nonimmunological phenomenon that presents with erythema, edema, vesicles, and/or oozing of the affected area. This patient's presentation with hypopigmented macules is unlikely to be due to irritant contact dermatitis.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Trichophyton can cause tinea corporis infection, which typically manifests with a round, pruritic, erythematous plaque that grows centrifugally, with central clearing, scaling, and a raised border. This patient's nonpruritic macules are unlikely due to tinea corporis infection.
Image Description:

An erythematous patch with mild scaling and central clearing is seen on the left wrist.

These features are characteristic of dermatophyte fungal infection.
